title: Greg Hardy win vs. Ben Sosoli changed to no contest due to his use of inhaler during bout
text:
Dave Doyle

MMA Junkie

With a little help from an inhaler, Greg Hardy earned his third UFC victory on Friday night – until it went away.

The controversial heavyweight was handily beating Ben Sosoli in the UFC on ESPN 6 main-card bout at Boston's TD Garden. But he was also noticeably slowing down and breathing heavy at the end of the second round.

Between rounds, Hardy (5-1 MMA, 2-1 UFC) took a hit from an inhaler. Then he went out and finished the third, and was originally awarded a unanimous decision on scores of 30-27 across the board. That result, however, was reversed and later ruled a no contest by the Massachusetts State Athletic Commission because of Hardy's inhaler use.

"I was in the ring. Me and my coach asked the commission if it would be OK to use my inhaler, and they said yes, so I took it," Hardy said. "I'm still a new guy in this sport. I did what I do in every situation: I asked permission. I got permission, and I did what I was told."

According to Yahoo! Sports' Kevin Iole, UFC president Dana White said use of the inhaler had been approved but that ultimately wasn't the case.

Hardy showed improved striking, footwork and pacing over the course of 15 minutes. He landed crisp jabs every time his smaller foe waded in, and he peppered Sosoli (7-2 MMA, 0-0 UFC) with kicks throughout the fight.

Sosoli – unlike some of Hardy's previous foes – didn't look intimidated and landed occasional heavy hands but he was never able to untrack any sustained offense.

It's the second controversial result for Hardy in the UFC. In his promotional debut back in January, Hardy was disqualified for throwing an illegal knee in a fight with Allen Crowder.

Hardy said post-fight that it was a "ventolin albuterol inhaler for exercise-induced asthma" that he's used his whole life. Hardy believes he did nothing wrong because he asked a Massachusetts State Athletic Commission official in the octagon if he could use the inhaler, citing U.S. Anti-Doping Agency approval.

That ultimately proved false, with Hardy’s victory being changed to a no contest, much to his dismay.

“The worst part is, here I am letting people down again,” Hardy said. “It’s a sucky feeling. All I’m trying to do is – we had a conversation before the fight, I’m doing everything I’m supposed to be doing. I asked permission, they told me I could, and I’m in trouble again. My mind’s on just make sure everyone is happy, making sure everything is cool because it’s a crappy feeling...

"I just fought more time than I’ve ever fought in my whole entire career, and we’re sitting here talking about an inhaler that I’ve used my whole entire life. That’s a crappy feeling, dude. I never want to take away from the UFC brand. I never want to take away from anybody, and I feel like that’s what’s happening, and I’m not OK with that.”

UFC president Dana White said he understands how it happened but it's still on Hardy's corner to "know you can’t use an inhaler in the corner. They should know that. Shouldn’t even be a question. You can drink water. It’s pretty simple. Gatorade in some states.”

Contributing: Mike Bohn
description: Greg Hardy used an inhaler during his fight with Ben Sosoli, and his unanimous decision win was changed to a no contest as a result.
